Title.evidence: CETUPANC Trial: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Surgical Approaches in Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the NT or SMA group.

Participants.evidence: Conducted across ten university hospitals, the trial included patients with resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC).

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the NT or SMA group.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the impact of the no-touch (NT) approach versus the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) approach in pancreatoduodenectomy on intraoperative circulating tumour cells (CTCs) and cluster mobilization, and their potential link to distant metastasis.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was intraoperative CTC and cluster mobilization, assessed at four time points.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was intraoperative, with allocation concealed until surgery.

Blinding.evidence: Patients were blinded to the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 101 patients were randomized (51 SMA, 50 NT) between January 2017 and December 2019.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Sixty-three patients with PDAC were analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Median metastasis disease-free survival (MDFS) was 12 months (IQR 6.1–not reached) in the SMA group and 18 months (IQR 12.1–not reached) in the NT group (P = 0.730).
